intro: Ferula elaeochytris, commonly known as the Persian cow's milk, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It is characterized by its tall, sparsely branched stem and its distinctive, narrow, lance-shaped leaves. The plant produces yellowish-green flowers arranged in umbellate clusters, which bloom in the summer months. Its roots are thick and fibrous, often containing a milky sap that has been traditionally used in herbal remedies. The plant is part of the Apiaceae family, sharing some morphological similarities with other members of the carrot and parsley group.
